author: jackfruh
body:
<!--

For Windows PowerShell 5.1 issues, suggestions, or feature requests please use the following link instead:
- Windows PowerShell [UserVoice](https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell)

If it is a bug report:
- make sure you are able to repro it on the latest released version. 
You can install the latest version from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases
- Search the existing issues.
- Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- Refer to the [known issues](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- Fill out the following repro template:

If it's not a bug, please remove the template and elaborate the issue in your own words.
-->

Steps to reproduce
------------------
Download beta 9 for mac pkg file from github
Install beta 9 powershell mac pkg on mac.
[optional: Confirm installer says beta 9]
start powershell - displays v6.0.0-beta.8
type $PSVERSIONTABLE

-displays
6.0.0-beta.8


```powershell

```

Expected behavior
-----------------

```none
Beta 9
```

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
Beta 8
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable

```

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: did you start as `powershell`?  You probably still have beta.8 side by side with beta.9.  You need to use `pwsh` to start beta.9.  Unfortunately there's no supported way to uninstall a .pkg (that I could find).  You can manually delete the beta.8 folder along with the /usr/bin/powershell symlink.

comments.author: thezim
comments.body:
@jackfruh If you're not interested in side by side this should get you back to zero if you installed from a `.pkg`. Then just reinstall beta 9.

```bash
sudo rm -rf /usr/local/microsoft /usr/local/bin/pwsh /usr/local/bin/powershell /Applications/PowerShell.app /usr/local/share/man/man1/pwsh.1.gz
sudo pkgutil --forget powershell
```

As @SteveL-MSFT  mentioned use `pwsh` if you're opening from a terminal. There is also a PowerShell icon in `Applications` folder in Finder that opens PowerShell as well.

comments.author: jackfruh
SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
@jackfruh the rename is listed in the breaking change section of the [release notes](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/tag/v6.0.0-beta.9)

I also [tweeted](https://twitter.com/Steve_MSFT/status/920706829058949120) it way before the release

title: Beta 9 - on mac showing as beta 8
